item.title: NATO Members’ Major Air Exercise Sends Message to Russia
item.description: More than 200 planes from 25 countries gathered in Germany for the largest-scale war games in decades, held with an eye on the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Ingo Gerhartz, second from left, of the German Air Force at the military air base in Wunstorf, Germany, on Monday.

item.title: Ukraine Claims More Small Advances in Counteroffensive
item.description: Military analysts said it would take weeks or months to gauge the success of the attacks Ukraine mounted last week across a broad stretch of the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers preparing to patrol an area of Kherson, southern Ukraine, that was flooded by the destruction of the Kakhovka dam, on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Lawmakers Ask White House to Punish South Africa for Supporting Russia
item.description: South Africa is accused of helping supply Russia with weapons for the Ukraine war, a charge that South Africa denies.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: The Lady R off Cape Town, South Africa, in December. Some U.S. officials say weapons were loaded onto the ship for Russia to use in Ukraine.

item.title: Cuban Government Is Responsible for Death of Oswaldo Payá, Report Says
item.description: The findings in the death of Oswaldo Payá contradict the Cuban government’s official version of what happened 11 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Frances Robles
item.category: Kennedy, Robert F, Center for Justice and Human Rights
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Oswaldo Payá in Havana, Cuba, in 2003. He was killed in a suspicious car crash in eastern Cuba that his family and supporters always believed had been caused by the government.

item.title: How Silvio Berlusconi Changed Italy
item.description: Whether as a politician or media tycoon, the former prime minister and businessman who died Monday at 86, left an imprint, or a bruise, on just about everything he touched.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi never anointed an heir to his center-right Forza Italia party, casting uncertainty on future of the coalition government of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni.

item.title: The Many Scandals of Silvio Berlusconi’s Career
item.description: The former prime minister of Italy reveled in the spotlight, even when it shined on him for causing offense.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi on the Greek island of Corfu in 1994.

item.title: Netanyahu Trial Gets a Hollywood Mention From a Political Rival
item.description: Yair Lapid, a former colleague and now nemesis of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, testified that he had been asked to help a wealthy film producer with a tax break.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Yair Lapid, the Israeli opposition leader, arriving to testify at the trial of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Monday.

item.title: A Saudi-China Business Conference Underscores Strengthening Ties
item.description: The kingdom hosted a lavish Arab-China business conference days after a visit from the American secretary of state, inviting companies blacklisted by the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.category: Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: The Saudi minister of energy, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, being interviewed during the 10th Arab-China Business Conference in Riyadh on Sunday.

item.title: Scotland’s Independence Movement Is Down, but Not Out, Analysts Say
item.description: Support for Scottish independence has dipped, but backing for Scotland remaining part of the United Kingdom is fragile, too. Nicola Sturgeon’s arrest leaves the fate of the movement in flux.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A protest in support of Scottish Independence in Glasgow last month.

item.title: The Guardian Apologizes for Its Handling of Sexual Harassment Complaints
item.description: The British media company is also changing its internal processes following a New York Times investigation into a former star political columnist.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Guardian and Observer building in the King’s Cross area of London.

item.title: Silvio Berlusconi’s Allies and Enemies React to His Death
item.description: The former Italian prime minister and media mogul, who died at 86, was a divisive figure, but even his foes acknowledged that he was an influential political and cultural force.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A mourner placing flowers and a note outside Silvio Berlusconi’s home in Arcore, Italy, on Monday.

item.title: Fear and Mayhem as Russia’s War Comes Home
item.description: Attacks from Ukraine have killed at least a dozen Russian civilians and displaced thousands. But they have not fundamentally changed the calculus for Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: China’s Coast Guard and the Fight to Control Asia
item.description: Beijing’s patrol vessels often resemble warships. Now other nations are trying to compete with tougher coast guards of their own.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Philippine Coast Guard personnel in an inflatable boat speeding past a Chinese Coast Guard cutter near a disputed shoal in the South China Sea in April.

item.title: ‘The State Killed My Brother’: Senegal in Uproar After Deadly Protests
item.description: After several protesters were killed by live ammunition this month in Senegal, many in the usually stable West African nation wonder what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Carmen Abd Ali
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: NATO air drills in Germany.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Ingo Gerhartz, second from left, of the German Air Force at the military air base in Wunstorf, Germany, on Monday.

item.title: 22 U.S. Troops Are Hurt in Helicopter ‘Mishap’ in Syria
item.description: The military provided few details about the accident, saying the troops had sustained “injuries of various degrees.”
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A U.S. military helicopter flying over Syria in 2020.

item.title: Black Rhinos, Horns Cut Off, Lose Some of Their Gusto
item.description: New research shows a conservation strategy can disrupt the animals’ social networks.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer
item.media:description: Trimming the horn of a tranquilized female black rhino in South Africa.

item.title: UN Nuclear Watchdog to Assess Dam Disaster Aftermath in Ukraine
item.description: Rafael Mariano Grossi said he would meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and present a plan for assistance in the aftermath of floods unleashed by the Kakhovka dam’s destruction.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant on the Dnipro River.

item.title: Militia in Congo Kills Dozens at Camp for Internally Displaced
item.description: The attack was attributed to a group that the United Nations says has killed hundreds of civilians in the region and forced thousands to flee.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: A camp for internally displaced people in Ituri Province of the Democratic Republic of Congo in 2021.

item.title: U.S. Will Rejoin UNESCO in July, Agency Says
item.description: The decision came after over a decade of turbulent relations between American administrations and the United Nation’s cultural organization.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: Audrey Azoulay, director-general of UNESCO, announcing the U.S. decision to rejoin the agency, at the UNESCO headquarters in Paris on Monday.

item.title: NATO Nations Open Giant Air Force Drills in Germany
item.description: More than 250 aircraft from 24 NATO countries and Japan will participate in a two-week military exercise.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Permission to Build
item.description: We’re covering a faster path to clean energy, the death of Silvio Berlusconi and the Tony Awards.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Christopher Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wind turbines at the Smoky Hills Wind Farm in Kansas in 2017.

item.title: Silvio Berlusconi, Polarizing Former Prime Minister of Italy, Dies at 86
item.description: He introduced sex and glamour to Italian TV and then brought the same formula to politics, dominating the country and its culture for more than 20 years.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Rachel Donadio
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi was at the forefront of Italian public life, off and on, for a quarter-century, serving as prime minister four times.

item.title: ‘Everything will die’: The dam blast imperils Ukraine’s vital lifeline.
item.description: A disaster unfolds in slow motion after a blast destroys the dam at the Kakhovka Reservoir, emptying its waters and threatening livelihoods and industries crucial to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Water levels upstream from the Kakhovka Dam have receded since its destruction, threatening life and industry dependent on the Kakhovka Reservoir, including the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon is arrested in Scotland.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:credit: Andrew Milligan/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon in April outside her home in Glasgow.

item.title: Ukraine Claims First Gains, if Slight, in Counteroffensive
item.description: Three small settlements in the eastern region of Donetsk have been taken back from Russian occupiers, Ukrainian officials say.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Soldiers with Ukraine’s Third Separate Assault Brigade south of Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: A U.S. Citizen Has Been Arrested in Russia, State Department Says
item.description: The man, Michael Travis Leake, has been accused of drug trafficking, according to Russian state media.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Adam Entous

item.title: Wagner Founder Rebuffs Order Requiring Contract With Russia’s Defense Ministry
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the private military force, said he would not comply with an order that would require it to sign a formal contract with Russia’s defense ministry by July 1.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: A billboard promoting service in the Wagner private mercenary group, on the outskirts of Saint Petersburg, Russia, last week.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s Former Leader, Is Arrested in Financial Inquiry
item.description: The arrest of Ms. Sturgeon, who resigned as leader of the Scottish National Party in February, follows that of her husband, previously the party’s chief executive, and of its former treasurer.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Milligan/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon in April outside her home in Glasgow.

item.title: Summer Reading
item.description: Melissa Kirsch takes a look at some of the big books coming this summer.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Ukraine Dam Destruction Threatens Those Upstream, Too
item.description: A disaster unfolds in slow motion after an explosion destroyed the dam at the Kakhovka Reservoir, emptying its waters and threatening livelihoods and crucial industries.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Flooding on Saturday in Kherson, Ukraine, after a dam on the Dnipro River collapsed.

item.title: India’s Train Crash Killed Mainly the Poor Packed in Cheapest Cars
item.description: In India’s worst railway disaster in decades, nearly all of the 288 dead were in three crowded cars where passengers stand for long stretches.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir, Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The train disaster site last Sunday in the Indian state of Odisha.

item.title: Iran Puts 2 Women Journalists on Trial for What They Wrote
item.description: Two female journalists, Niloufar Hamedi and Elaheh Mohammadi, covered some of the first reports of the death of Mahsa Amini in police custody, which ignited nationwide protests against Iran’s clerical rulers.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:description: A photograph posted on social media of the imprisoned Iranian reporters Niloufar Hamedi and Elaheh Mohammadi, who are now on trial.

item.title: Aussie Farmers Unleash Dinosaur Rush as Fossils Rewrite History
item.description: A new understanding of how to search for ancient remains has reinvigorated a region of western Queensland, with tourists flocking to paleontological digs.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Elliott, a fourth-generation farmer, became an accidental paleontologist, and then the founder and chairman of a museum that draws thousands of visitors a year.

item.title: China Has Had a Spy Base in Cuba for Years, U.S. Official Says
item.description: It was unclear whether the report might complicate Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s rescheduled trip to Beijing for meetings that begin June 18.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Edward Wong
item.media:description: The Senate Intelligence Committee is disturbed by the cooperation of Beijing and Havana.

item.title: 4 Missing Colombian Children Are Rescued and Said to Be in Good Health
item.description: The four siblings, ages 1 to 13, were eager to play and asked for books just a day after being rescued and having survived 40 days in the jungle, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: The four Colombian children who survived in the jungle for 40 days after their plane crashed were transported to a military hospital in Bogotá after being rescued on Friday.

item.title: Greta Thunberg Ends Her School Strikes After 251 Weeks
item.description: The climate activist, who has inspired young people around the world to demand action against climate change, graduated from high school on Friday in Sweden.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: Greta Thunberg with a sign that reads “School Strike for Climate” outside the Swedish Parliament on Friday, the day of her weekly protest, in Stockholm.

item.title: Last Reactor at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Shuts Down After Dam Collapse
item.description: The lone reactor that was still operating at Europe’s largest nuclear plant was shut down because of the threat to its water supply. The reactor had been helping supply energy to the plant itself.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: The last reactor of the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, in the background, was put into a “cold shutdown.”

item.title: Zelensky Signals Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Has Begun
item.description: As waters from the flooding of a burst dam began to recede, Ukrainian forces were trying to break through stout Russian defenses in the south and east.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers operating a drone several miles south of Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine on Saturday. President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine indicated on Saturday that his country’s troops were engaged in offensive actions in the south and east.

item.title: Pope’s Doctors Say He’s on the Mend, but Advise Rest and No Events
item.description: Francis, who had abdominal surgery on Wednesday, has been advised by his medical team to rest and not recite his usual weekly prayer from his hospital balcony on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The Policlinico A. Gemelli hospital in Rome where Pope Francis is recovering.

item.title: Annecy Stabbings Lead to Charges Against Syrian Refugee
item.description: A local prosecutor said that the six victims of the attack, two adults and four very young children, were no longer in life-threatening conditions.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A memorial for victims of the attack in the Jardins de l’Europe park in Annecy, France.

item.title: Global Reaction to Trump Indictment Runs the Gamut
item.description: Allies and rivals alike, beholding the messiness of America, must calculate the risks and opportunities in the latest plot twist in Donald Trump’s legal troubles.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The world, it seems, is calculating the costs and opportunities of the latest Trump revelations transfixing and dividing the United States after former President Donald J. Trump was indicted.

item.title: Col. Lanny Acosta, Guantánamo Judge, Faces Ethics Challenge
item.description: The issue has cast a cloud over the coming proceedings in the U.S.S. Cole bombing case, which are scheduled to last three weeks starting Monday.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Camp Justice is where the military commission proceedings are held for detainees charged with war crimes.

item.title: Boris Johnson’s Comeback Hopes May Be Dimmer Than He Thinks
item.description: The former British prime minister, who resigned from Parliament on Friday, has found his way back into voters’ good graces before. But analysts say there is now almost no plausible path back to power for him.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain at Westminster Hall in London in February. He was a member of Parliament until Friday, when he resigned suddenly.

item.title: Trump’s Indictment Is Unavoidably Political
item.description: The prosecutors’ audience is not only the judge and jurors. It is also the American public.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: Federal Criminal Case Against Trump (Documents Case)
item.media:description: Jack Smith, the special counsel assigned to lead the investigation into Donald Trump.

item.title: Orange and Smoky Skies Over a Province That Rolled Back Climate Measures
item.description: Doug Ford, Ontario’s premier, has a long history of opposition to renewable energy programs and an agenda that favors highway construction.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Smoke and haze from wildfires in Ontario and Quebec over Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Tuesday.

item.title: With Probes of Russian Lines, Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Takes Shape
item.description: Ukraine is using its new arsenal of Western tanks and armored vehicles in what is expected to be one of the largest military operations in Europe since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing from an armored fighting vehicle several miles south of Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Arizona, Low on Water, Weighs Taking It From the Sea. In Mexico.
item.description: A $5 billion plan to desalinate seawater in Mexico and pipe it to Phoenix is testing the notion that desert cities can keep growing as the Earth warms.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Adriana Zehbrauskas
item.media:description: Shrimp boats in Puerto Peñasco, Mexico, after a day of fishing in the Gulf of California.

item.title: From ‘Pariah’ to Partner, Saudi Leader Defies Threats to Isolate Him
item.description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has repeatedly leveraged Saudi Arabia’s wealth and influence to overcome international condemnation of the kingdom’s human rights violations.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Bandar Al-Jaloud/Saudi Press Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Saudi state news media showing Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman chairing the 43rd session of the Gulf Cooperation Council in Riyadh, on the sidelines of the Gulf Arab Chinese Summit in December.

item.title: Colombia’s Mustard Lovers Grow Desperate Amid Dijon Shortage
item.description: Colombians are scrambling to find the beloved French condiment as a new health law removes it from shelves, leaving a tangy void in their hearts and sandwiches.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steak tartare with mustard at Flambeé, a popular French restaurant in Bogotá.

item.title: As Ukraine Launches Counteroffensive, Definitions of ‘Success’ Vary
item.description: Privately, U.S. and European officials concede that pushing all of Russia’s forces out of occupied Ukrainian land is highly unlikely.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces firing at Russian positions in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine on Wednesday.

item.title: What to Know About Canada’s Exceptional Wildfire Season
item.description: Wild fires started earlier, are higher in number and spread across much of the country, burning millions of acres as climate change turns more of the country’s forest into a tinderbox.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: The smoke from multiple wildfires last month in Edmonton, Alberta.

item.title: Children Missing in Amazon Jungle Found Alive After 40 Days
item.description: Rescuers had been searching for the children — aged 13, 9, 4 and 1 — ever since they survived a plane crash that killed the three adults on board.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Colombia’s Armed Forces Press Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Colombia Armed Forces soldiers and Indigenous search team members with the four children who had been missing since May 1, when the plane they were on crashed in the rainforest.

item.title: Children Killed in Somalia Mortar Shell Explosion
item.description: A previously unexploded mortar shell went off as children were playing around it in a city in southern Somalia.
item.dc:creator: Reuters

item.title: Canada’s Ability to Prevent Forest Fires Lags Behind the Need
item.description: Provincial firefighting agencies are stretched thin, there is no national agency and it’s hard to get approval for controlled burns — factors that have exacerbated recent outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of Quebec’s forest firefighting agency, in Roberval, where all operations for the northern part of the province are managed.

item.title: Battles Rage as Ukraine Tries to Retake Russian-Occupied Territory
item.description: Military analysts and U.S. officials said it was too soon to judge the success of Ukraine’s offensive, which is looking for weaknesses to exploit, in the face of fierce resistance.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: The 3rd Separate Assault Brigade of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, at the front line south of Bakhmut on Friday.

item.title: How to Help Thousands of Canadians Displaced by Wildfires
item.description: Federal and provincial governments have pledged to match donations to the Canadian Red Cross for those affected by wildfires in Nova Scotia, Alberta and the Northwest Territories.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Camp beds set up to accommodate displaced people from Chibougamau, Quebec, in the Roberval emergency center.

item.title: Boris Johnson Resigns From Parliament
item.description: The former prime minister quit after getting a confidential report about whether he had lied to lawmakers about lockdown-breaking parties.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Boris Johnson has been under investigation over whether he lied to Parliament over lockdown-breaking parties in Downing Street during the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Pope Francis and Silvio Berlusconi Both Hospitalized in Italy
item.description: The health conditions of two of Italy’s most prominent octogenarians have in recent years often kept the country in suspense.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the apostolic palace overlooking St. Peter’s Square in The Vatican this week.
